content.webTitle: Sattler's standard demands a stand. His Gillard question was disrespectful

fields.headline: Sattler's standard demands a stand. His Gillard question was disrespectful
fields.bodyText: “The standard you walk past is the standard you accept.” That was part of what the chief of army, Lt Gen David Morrison told army members on Thursday night in a video message as he explained that if they felt it necessary to demean their female colleagues, or if they turned a blind eye to the demeaning behaviour of others, they should find another job. Morrison was responding to allegations that have been referred to the police. But his point about standards is broadly applicable. Howard Sattler’s utterly disrespectful question to the prime minister about the sexuality of the man who has been her life partner for the past seven years was for many people so below any acceptable standard they simply could not walk past. The weaselly “it’s not me saying it ... you hear it – he must be gay, he’s a hairdresser” cop-out lines just made it worse. But many people have been “walking past” escalating vitriol, not to mention wilful inaccuracies, from some radio announcers for a long, long time. Over on 2GB Alan Jones (he of “put her in a chaff bag, take her out to sea and dump her” and her father must have “died of shame” infamy) was busy lambasting the prime minister’s “blue ties” speech this week. I think there are some legitimate questions to ask about that speech. There might be only two women in the shadow cabinet, but their presence surely means women’s voices won’t be completely “banished” in an Abbott government. And it’s unclear how abortion law would become a “plaything” of men under the Coalition when both major parties have both pro-choice and pro-life MPs and Abbott has said he won’t change federal law, especially since he has now also promised not to do deals with DLP senator John Madigan. But Jones was not asking questions. He wasn’t even just stating a view. He was, as usual, venting. In fact, he was calling the prime minister sick, irrational and evil. Her speech, he told his listeners, proved Gillard was “so consumed with jealousy and anger and hatred that rationality has abandoned her thinking”. “I’m sorry. Julia Gillard has reached the end of the road. She is either ill, with envy, jealous envy, anger and humiliation or she is a seriously evil woman ... Forget misogyny, this woman by her speech yesterday is a misanthrope, a hater of men,” he said. "Anyone visiting the country would believe that this was a person who is seriously in need of emotional and psychological help … I’ve said many times and I say it again, there is no limit to the depths to which this woman will sink in order to save herself." It went on, and on. Jones is free to express his views. But listeners, to him, to Sattler and to the rest of the venting shock jocks around the nation, need to decide whether they want to “walk past” when they hear questions such as Sattler’s, or statements such as Jones’s that the prime minister of the country is “seriously evil”. Some already have taken a stand. But everyone who finds a comment offensive, below a reasonable standard of debate or questioning, and continues to walk past, helps acceptance of the unacceptable.
